title: I am filing Chapter 7 next week. Is my Mutual Fund/Retirement protected or should I sell first and pay IRS?
question: I also transferred two vehicles out of my name to my son (his and his girlfriend's primary vehicles). They are old and of little value (1995/1999). I am unemployed, disabled and have no income. Thank you!
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Tax law,Representing yourself
answers: Transferring title to the vehicles may or may not be a problem. It depends on their value. You should see a Bankruptcy Attorney to make sure that you are not "jumping from the frying pan into the fire". There is a way of disclosing the transfer and protecting its integrity in the bankruptcy. Do not do anything with respect to your retirement funds until you speak to a bankruptcy attorney. It is never a good idea to pay things off, transfer property or funds prior to filing a Chapter 7 bankruptcy. That being said, a good bankruptcy attorney should be able to help you make sure that you are not doing anything to jeopardize your retirement funds.
A qualified IRS is exempt. Speak with an experienced attorney to see if your IRS is qualified.

If your Mutual Fund is a qualified retirement account, it is exempt. You will need to disclose the vehicle transfers but it is unlikely the trustee will pursue the vehicles due the modest value there. Good luck.

If the "Mutual Fund/Retirement" meets the bankruptcy guidelines for exemption, it is protected. Consult with an attorney to find out. If your IRS debt is a few years old, it could be discharged in a bankruptcy. Consult with an attorney to find out. Transfers of property without a fair payment in exchange can be reversed, and since you did not want the property (you gave it away), it will be liquidated to pay to your creditors. Some of these mistakes can be corrected with competent counsel. Seek the assistance of an attorney before you make more mistakes.

You need a bankruptcy attorney. These things have to be examined and this is not a forum for specific advice. While retirement accounts are protected, mutual funds are in a different category than retirement accounts and you would need to have sufficient wildcard exemption available to do so. The transfers may or may not be an issue. Far greater analysis is needed than can be provided on this website. Please read my recently written legal guide about the pitfalls of representing yourself in bankruptcy. Here is the link: https://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/filing-bankruptcy-without-an-attorney-what-you-don-t-know-can-hurt-you
